CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6-1;Violation of P4-2-2;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE , GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was driving from GPE and crossed the border to GPE at the checkpoint at Maljevac . He was stopped by a customs officer for a routine check .

CARDINAL . The applicant gives the following account of what happened at the border checkpoint . Before arriving in GPE , the applicant and another person , GPE , had purchased CARDINAL cartons of cigarettes and QUANTITY of cooking oil .

CARDINAL . At the border checkpoint they were approached by a customs officer who asked the applicant if he had anything to declare . The applicant pointed at the purchased goods , lying in the backseat of the car , inviting the customs officer to take a look . The officer then asked the applicant to show him his passport . While holding the applicant 's passport the officer told the applicant that he had failed to declare the goods and thus committed a customs offence . He asked the applicant to pay a fine in the amount of CARDINAL NORP PERSON ( hereinafter HRK ) .

CARDINAL . NORP The applicant told the officer that he could not pay the fine right away because he did not have enough money on him . The officer did not return the applicant 's passport and told him that he would receive his passport when he had paid the fine . The applicant then continued to GPE .

CARDINAL . The Government gave the following account of the facts . While entering GPE the applicant failed to declare goods that he had purchased in GPE . However , a customs officer found CARDINAL cartons of cigarettes and QUANTITY of cooking oil in the applicant 's car . He routinely fined the applicant with HRK CARDINAL [ QUANTITY ] for a minor customs offence . The applicant was immediately given a document which stated that he was fined with HRK CARDINAL for having failed to declare CARDINAL cartons of cigarettes he was importing . The applicant signed the document . During this procedure the applicant 's passport was kept by the customs officer , who had intended to return it to the applicant . However , the applicant refused to pay the fine and demonstratively drove away , leaving his passport behind .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant wrote from his address in PERSON to ORG , ORG asking that his passport be returned .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG replied to the applicant 's address in PERSON that the custom officers acted in accordance with law when they seized the applicant 's passport because he had refused to pay the fine for a customs offence which he had committed by failing to declare goods at a border checkpoint . They relied on Sections CARDINAL to CARDINAL of LAW which , inter alia , provided that a person , while crossing a customs check point , had to declare and show all goods that he was importing . Failure to declare such goods represented a customs offence . The letter also stated that since the applicant had not declared the goods that he had been importing to GPE , he had committed a customs offence under LAW and fined pursuant to LAW . The applicant 's passport had been kept because the applicant had refused to pay the fine . The letter contained no indication of how and when the applicant 's passport would be returned .
CARDINAL . Although the applicant did not pay the imposed fine no other proceedings were instituted against him for the alleged customs offence .

CARDINAL . In the meantime , on DATE , ORG , apparently having decided not to institute any further proceedings against the applicant , handed over the passport to ORG . The Police noticed , however , that the applicant was registered as living in GPE for which reason , on DATE , the passport was sent to ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG wrote to the applicant 's registered address in GPE inviting him to collect his passport . The letter was returned . On DATE ORG wrote once more to the applicant , but the letter was again returned . The receipt showed that the applicant was unknown at that address .

CARDINAL . The Police discovered subsequently that the applicant , although registered as living in GPE , actually lived in PERSON . On DATE the passport was sent to ORG which invited the applicant to collect his passport . He did so on DATE .

CARDINAL . Having received the ORG letter of CARDINAL DATE the applicant filed a civil suit on DATE in ORG against ORG , seeking the return of his passport and damages flowing from his inability to leave GPE . He also requested the court to adopt an interim measure and order that his passport be returned to him immediately .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant also filed an application in the ORG claiming that the seizure of his passport by a customs officer was an unlawful act and that therefore , his right to freedom of movement had been violated . He requested the court to order ORG to return his passport forthwith .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant 's claim . It found that a claim for protection from an unlawful act was permitted only if there was no other remedy available . In the opinion of the court the applicant had at his disposal another remedy - a civil action for the return of his property . Accordingly , it instructed the applicant to institute civil proceedings in a municipal court against ORG for the return of his passport .
CARDINAL . The applicant appealed against the decision .
CARDINAL . NORP The applicant 's appeal was rejected on DATE by ORG ( PERSON ) .
CARDINAL . In the meantime , at a hearing on DATE ORG , in the proceedings instituted on DATE , against ORG , separated the applicant 's claim for damages from the claim for return of the passport .

CARDINAL . Concerning the claim for return of the applicant 's passport the next hearing was held on DATE . At that hearing the court heard the applicant and then decided to hear ORG , who was with the applicant in the car at the material time . It was furthermore agreed between the parties to adjourn the issue of damages pending the outcome of the claim for the return of the passport .

CARDINAL . At a hearing on DATE the court heard the customs officer who took the applicant 's passport . It also invited the applicant to submit within DATE a copy of the letter that he had sent to ORG as well as their reply .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant submitted ORG reply of CARDINAL DATE .

CARDINAL . At a hearing on DATE the court heard another customs officer and once again the applicant . It then rejected the applicant 's request for an interim measure finding that the applicant 's main claim , i.e. to have his passport returned , was exactly the same as his request for the interim measure and that , therefore , such a request could only be decided after the court established all the relevant facts of the case .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant filed an application asking that the judge be removed from the case . On DATE the President of ORG rejected the applicant 's motion .

CARDINAL . The next hearing was held on DATE . The applicant informed the court that on DATE ORG had returned his passport . Therefore , he no longer sought the return of his passport but instead sought a declaratory decision to the effect that on DATE his passport was taken from him by the NORP authorities and returned on DATE . He also sought costs .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant filed submissions with the court repeating the statements and claims he made at the hearing on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant 's counsel appeared before the judge and agreed to reformulate the applicant 's claim having regard to the fact that the passport had already been returned to him .

CARDINAL . The next hearing was held on DATE during which it was formally recorded that the passport had been returned to the applicant . The applicant 's counsel sought from the court permission to specify the applicant 's remaining claims . The court allowed her to do so within DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant himself filed submissions to the court reiterating the same claims as those submitted on DATE . No additional claims were submitted by the applicant 's counsel .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant again filed an application asking that the judge be removed from the case . The President of the court accepted the request and the case was transferred to another judge .

CARDINAL . Following a hearing on DATE the court dismissed the applicant 's claims . It found that the applicant had no further legal interest in seeking a declaratory decision that his passport had been taken from him by the NORP authorities on DATE and then returned on DATE . The applicant was also ordered to pay the defendant 's costs .

CARDINAL . The applicant 's subsequent appeal was dismissed and the first instance decision was upheld by ORG ( Županijski sud u GPE ) on DATE . It held that the applicant had no legal interest in seeking a declaratory decision and that ORG decision on the costs of the proceedings was well - founded because the applicant had lost his case .
CARDINAL . According to the applicant the proceedings concerning his claim for damages have never been resumed and on DATE the case was closed without any decision on the merits been taken .
CARDINAL . According to the Government the case has not been closed and the proceedings are still pending .

CARDINAL . According to Sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Act on Travel Documents of NORP Citizens ( Zakon o putnim ispravama hrvatskih građana - ORG no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , hereinafter LAW on Travel Documents ” ) a passport will be seized when there is a reasonable suspicion that :
- a person is acting against the laws regulating customs or foreign trade .
CARDINAL . Relevant parts of LAW ( PERSON , ORG no . ORG ) provides , inter alia , that a person who , when crossing a border , does not declare the goods for his or her personal use shall be fined .
